metadata.case_name: Jiyajeerao Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954 and Civil Appeal No. 163 of 1958

facts.text: Appellant is a public limited company incorporated in 1921 under the Gwalior Companies Act, carries on business in manufacture and sale of textiles, registered office at Gwalior, non-resident company for purposes of the Act, managing agents Birla Brothers Ltd. registered in British India.
Appellant received Rs. 27,30,094 during account year 1942-1943, admits these represent profits on forward contracts in cotton.
Proceedings under section 34 of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 to tax the sum of Rs. 27,30,094.

Appellant contends contracts entered into at Gwalior with brokers Lashkar Trading Company, Banwarilal Shivkumar and Meghraj Mundra, agreements provide for delivery and payment at Gwalior, differences paid in settlement at Gwalior, profits accrued and received wholly at Gwalior.
Department contends contracts entered into by managing agents with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad at Bombay, profits accrued in Bombay.
Sum of Rs. 27,30,094 traceable to Jwaladutt Kishanprasad.

Appellant's version of dealings: Orders placed with three Gwalior brokers, who placed orders with J.R. Pillani Gwalior (branch of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad Bombay), orders communicated to Bombay head office, settlements paid by Bombay firm to J.R. Pillani Gwalior, then to brokers, then to appellant.
Income-tax Officer order dated March 23, 1948: Contracts entered by managing agents at Bombay, brokers dummies.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed ITO order on November 14, 1949.
Appellate Tribunal remanded case on July 26, 1950 for further investigation.

Appellate Assistant Commissioner report dated August 17, 1951 after examining seven witnesses: Contracts entered with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad by G.D. Birla and R.D. Birla at Bombay, broker contracts bogus.
Appellate Tribunal affirmed on February 28, 1952.
Tribunal dismissed reference application under s.66(1) on June 13, 1952.
Bombay High Court (Chagla CJ, Bhagwati J) dismissed s.66(2) application on August 6, 1952.

Pillani (proprietor of Jwaladutt Kishanprasad Bombay and J.R. Pillani Gwalior) testified contracts made at Bombay by G.D. Birla and R.D. Birla in person or phone, initial profits to Cotton Agents Ltd. Bombay, later routed to Gwalior, initial entries with blank names later filled as J.R. Pillani Gwalior.
Accounts show transactions involving Cotton Agents Ltd. Bombay, J.R. Pillani Bombay, adjustments from Feb-Mar 1943.
Three brokers: No prior/subsequent cotton futures business, no bank accounts, large cash payments alleged, ankdas freshly written, no securities held despite huge transactions.
Appellant had genuine large transactions with Cotton Agents Ltd. Gwalior but not used for these.
Appellant's transactions with brokers entered in Kherij Khata for small/short-term dealings, but these were large/long-term.
Contracts recite principals, delivery/payment at Gwalior, but per East India Cotton Association bye-laws, contracts take effect in Bombay, delivery in Bombay.

legal_issues.text: Whether the forward contracts resulting in profits of Rs. 27,30,094 were entered into at Gwalior or at Bombay, determining if profits accrued/arose in British India and taxable under the Act.
Whether any question of law arises from Tribunal's order, or if it is pure question of fact; whether Tribunal's finding is vitiated by no evidence or perversity.

petitioner_arguments.text: Contracts entered at Gwalior with three brokers, profits settled at Gwalior, not liable to tax.
Tribunal's finding that contracts at Bombay has no evidence or is perverse, erroneous in law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax (finding of fact open to attack if no evidence or perverse)

petitioner_arguments.text: Pillani's evidence contradicted by accounts and other witnesses, infirmities ignored by Tribunal.
Brokers' contracts genuine, recite principals and Gwalior delivery.
No evidence from Birlas taken despite remand order.

respondent_arguments.text: Contracts entered by managing agents (Birlas) with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad at Bombay, brokers dummies to conceal.
Brokers not credible for large transactions, no accounts/securities, fresh ankdas.
Veil too thin if directly with J.R. Pillani Gwalior, hence brokers used.
Contracts per East India Cotton Association rules made in Bombay.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Bye-law No. 44-A of East India Cotton Association

court_reasoning.text: Whether question of law: Pure question of fact where contracts made, Tribunal finding final unless no evidence or perverse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finding supported by Pillani's direct testimony and circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: Pillani's evidence accepted: Contracts at Bombay by Birlas, initial profits to Cotton Agents Bombay, later routed; blanks in accounts filled later.
Criticisms of Pillani's evidence (e.g., Rs.9,50,000) not material; other payments directly from Jwaladutt to Cotton Agents relate to cotton.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Tribunal could reasonably find transactions as per Pillani.

court_reasoning.text: Brokers' evidence weak: No means, no prior business, cash dealings, no securities, Kherij Khata inappropriate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Contracts sham to conceal Bombay dealings.

court_reasoning.text: No misdirection; remand covered examination of relevant persons, Birlas not compelled to testify.

holdings.text: Tribunal's finding that contracts entered at Bombay is one of fact, supported by evidence, not perverse; profits accrued in British India, taxable.
No question of law arises; finding not erroneous in law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Meenakshi Mills v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: When finding of fact open to attack: no evidence or perverse.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Proceedings to tax escaped income; reference to court.

statutes_cited.name: Bye-laws of East India Cotton Association
statutes_cited.relevance: Contracts take effect as made in Bombay.

outcome.summary: Both appeals dismissed as Tribunal's finding that forward contracts were entered into at Bombay by managing agents with Jwaladutt Kishanprasad, profits accrued there and taxable, is a finding of fact supported by evidence including Pillani's testimony and circumstances; no question of law arises.
outcome.costs: Respondent gets costs in Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1954; parties bear own costs in Civil Appeal No. 163 of 1958.

key_quotes.text: "A finding on a question of fact is open to attack under section 66(1) as erroneous in law when there is no evidence to support or if it is perverse."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Test for interfering with Tribunal's factual finding.

key_quotes.text: "Every person is entitled so to arrange his affairs as to avoid taxation but the arrangement must be real and genuine and not a sham or make-believe."
key_quotes.speaker: court
